Class MainScreenController

java.lang.Object
com.example.software_1_project.MainScreenController
All Implemented Interfaces:
javafx.fxml.Initializable
public class MainScreenController extends Object implements javafx.fxml.Initializable
This controls all features of the main screen.

  • Method Details

    • initialize

      public void initialize(URL url, ResourceBundle resourceBundle)
      This preloads the tables with data if parts and products lists are empty, and it is the first time launching the program.

      LOGICAL ERROR: At first I tried to set the 'firstTime' variable from true to false in the initialize method, however this caused it to always be set to true or always set to false. So the fields would always populate or never populate. To fix this I moved the variable to MainScreen.java and only allowed that class to get and set it.
      Specified by:
      initialize in interface javafx.fxml.Initializable

      public void displayProdSearch()
      Method used to search for products. FUTURE ENHANCEMENT: The ability to search for products by parts associated.

    • onClick2DeletePart

      public boolean onClick2DeletePart()
      Method for deleting parts.

    • onClick2DeleteProduct

      public boolean onClick2DeleteProduct()
      Method for deleting products. BUG FIX: Deleting a product caused the associated parts to be deleted as well. This was fixed by checking if the selected item's associated parts list was empty or not. If not, the user is given a warning that the product has parts associated and cannot be deleted.

    • sendWarning

      public void sendWarning(javafx.scene.control.Button button, javafx.scene.control.TextField textField, String x)
      Method to create warning when no search matches are found. LOGICAL ERROR: The button parameter was only being set to call displayPartSearch(). This caused the product pane search button onAction to the wrong method. To fix this, I included a string parameter ("part" or "product") passed in to this function by the search methods. This determines which method the button parameter is coming from and which method its onAction should be set to.

    • onExitButtonClick

      protected void onExitButtonClick()
      Exits the program.
